lesson.name: Lesson 9.6 Teacher Guide: The Quadratic Formula

page.title: 9.6.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

In this lesson, students encounter the quadratic formula and learn that it can be used to solve any quadratic equation. They use the formula and verify that it produces the same solutions as those found using other methods but can be much more practical for certain equations.

In upcoming lessons, students will continue to develop their understanding of the formula and its structure by using it to solve contextual problems and by analyzing its parts. After students have gained some experience working with the formula, they will investigate how it is derived.

Using the quadratic formula to solve equations requires students to attend carefully to the parameters in the given equations and to apply different properties of operations flexibly as they reason symbolically.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Recognize that the solutions obtained using the quadratic formula are the same as those found by using factored form or by completing the square.
  • Use the quadratic formula to solve quadratic equations of the form \(ax^2+bx+c=0\).

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Use the quadratic formula to solve quadratic equations.
  • Explain when some methods for solving quadratic equations can be more convenient than others.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A8(A) solve quadratic equations having real solutions by factoring, taking square roots, completing the square, and applying the quadratic formula.

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

A11(A) simplify numerical radical expressions involving square roots.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 9.6.1: Evaluating Expressions
  • 9.6.2: Choosing the Best Method to Solve an Equation
    • 9.6.2: Self Check
    • 9.6.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.6.3: The Quadratic Formula
    • 9.6.3: Self Check
    • 9.6.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.6.4: Solving Equations Using the Quadratic Formula

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 9.6.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Scientific calculators

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson.
  • Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in "math talk" and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • radical expression
  • completing the square
  • perfect square
  • quadratic formula

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their intellectual humility.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • Facing the Future
  • A Lesson in Active Learning

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Intellectual Humility from Character Lab.

page.title: 9.6.1: Evaluating Expressions
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm up prompts students to evaluate the kinds of numerical expressions they will see in the lesson. The expressions involve rational square roots, fractions, and the \(\pm\) notation.

As students work, notice any common errors or challenges so they can be addressed during the class discussion.

Launch

Tell students to evaluate the expressions without using a calculator.

Student Activity

Each expression represents two numbers. Evaluate the expressions and find the two numbers.

  1. \(1 \pm\sqrt{49}\)
  • 8
  • 50
  • -48
  • -6

Answer: 8, -6

  1. \(\frac{8 \pm2}{5}\)
  • \( \frac45\)
  • 2
  • \(\frac{16}{5}\)
  • \(\frac{6}{5}\)

Answer: 2, \(\frac65\)

  1. \(\pm \; \sqrt{(-5)^2-4 \cdot 4 \cdot 1}\)
  • \( \sqrt{-6}\)
  • 3
  • -3
  • \(- \sqrt{-6}\)

Answer: 3, -3

  1. \(\frac{-18 \pm \sqrt{36}}{2 \cdot3}\)
  • -2
  • -17
  • -19
  • -4

Answer: -2, -4

Anticipated Misconceptions

Students may be unfamiliar with evaluating rational expressions in which the numerator contains more than one term. To help students see the structure of the expressions, consider decomposing them into a sum of two fractions. For example, show that \(\frac{8 \pm \; 2}{5}\) can be written as \(\frac{8}{5} \pm \frac{2}{5}\). This approach can also help to avoid a common error of dividing only the first term by the denominator \((\frac{4+7}{2} \neq 2+7)\). Some students may incorrectly write \(\frac{ \sqrt{36}}{2}\) as \(\sqrt{18}\). Point out that the first expression is equal to 3 while the other has to be greater than 3 since \(\sqrt{18} \approx 4.243\).

Activity Synthesis

Select students to share their responses and reasoning. Address any common errors. As needed, remind students of the properties and order of operations and the meaning and use of the \(\pm\) symbol.

page.title: 9.6.2: Choosing the Best Method to Solve an Equation
page.contents:
Activity (10 minutes)

In this activity, students encounter equations that are challenging to solve using the methods they have learned, motivating students to seek a more efficient method.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of two. Ask partners to choose the same equation. Give students quiet time to solve the equation and then time to discuss their solutions and strategy. If they finish solving their chosen equation, ask them to choose another one to solve. Leave a few minutes for a whole-class discussion.

Provide access to calculators for numerical computations.

Student Activity

Write down your answer for how to solve each equation. Find the two solutions by rewriting it in factored form or by completing the square. Be prepared to explain your choice of method.

  1. Select two solutions for \(x^2−2x−1.25=0\).
  • 2.5
  • 3
  • -1
  • -0.5

Answer: 2.5, -0.5

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: Completing the square method:

\(\begin{array}{rcl} x^{2}-2 x-1.25 &=&0 \\ x^{2}-2 x &=&1.25 \\ x^{2}-2 x+\left(\frac{-2}{2}\right)^{2} &=&1.25+\left(\frac{-2}{2}\right)^{2} \\ x^{2}-2 x+1 &=&1.25+1 \\ x^{2}-2 x+1 &=&2.25 \\ (x-1)^{2} &=&2.25 \\ \sqrt{(x-1)^{2}} &=&\sqrt{2.25} \\ x-1 &=&\pm \sqrt{2.25} \\ x &=&1 \pm \sqrt{2.25} \\ x &=&1 \pm 1.5 \\ x &=&1+1.5 \\ x &=&1-1.5 \\ x &=&2.5 \\ x &=&-0.5 \\ x&=&2.5 \text { and } x=-0.5 \end{array}\)

  1. Select two solutions for \(5x^2+9x−44=0\).
  • 2.2
  • -20
  • -4
  • 11

Answer: 2.2, -4

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: Completing the square method:

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 5 x^{2}+9 x-44 &=&0 \\ 5 x^{2}+9 x &=&44 \\ \frac{5 x^{2}+9 x}{5} &=&\frac{44}{5} \\ x^{2}+\frac{9}{5} x+\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{9}{5}\right)^{2} &=&\frac{44}{5}+\left(\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{9}{5}\right)^{2} \\ x^{2}+\frac{9}{5} x+\frac{81}{100} &=&\frac{44}{5}+\frac{81}{100} \\ x^{2}+\frac{9}{5} x+\frac{81}{100} &=&\frac{961}{100} \\ \left(x+\frac{9}{10}\right)^{2} &=&\frac{961}{100} \\ \sqrt{\left(x+\frac{9}{10}\right)^{2}} &=&\sqrt{\frac{961}{100}} \\ x+\frac{9}{10} &=&\pm \frac{31}{10} \\ x &=&-\frac{9}{10} \pm \frac{31}{10} \\ x &=&-\frac{9}{10}+\frac{31}{10} \\ x &=&-\frac{9}{10}-\frac{31}{10} \\ x &=&\frac{22}{10}=2.2\\ x&=&-\frac{40}{10}=-4 \\ x&=&2.2 \text { and } x=-4 \end{array}\)

  1. Select two solutions for \(x^2+1.25x=0.375\).
  • 0.75
  • 0.25
  • -1.5
  • 2.5

Answer: 0.25, -1.5

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: Completing the square method:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+1.25 x &=0.375 \\ x^{2}+1.25 x+((0.5)(1.25))^{2} &=0.375+((0.5)(1.25)){ }^{2} \\ x^{2}+1.25 x+0.390625 &=0.375+0.390625 \\ (x+0.625)^{2} &=0.765625 \\ \sqrt{(x+0.625)^{2}} &=\sqrt{0.765625} \\ x+0.625 &=\pm 0.875 \\ x &=-0.625 \pm 0.875 \\ x &=-0.625+0.875 \\ x &=-0.625-0.875 \\ x &=0.25 \\ x &=-1.5 \\ x=0.25 & \text { and } x=-1.5 \end{aligned}\)

  1. Select two solutions for \(4x^2−28x+29=0\).
  • \(-7+ \sqrt{2}\)
  • \(7- \sqrt{2}\)
  • \(\frac{7}{2}+\sqrt{5}\)
  • \(\frac{7}{2}- \sqrt{5}\)

Answer: \(\frac{7}{2}+ \sqrt{5}\), \(\frac{7}{2}- \sqrt{5}\)

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: Completing the square method:

\(\begin{array}{rcl} 4 x^{2}-28 x+29 &=&0 \\ \frac{4 x^{2}-28 x+29}{4} &=&0 \\ x^{2}-7 x+\frac{29}{4} &=&0 \\ x^{2}-7 x &=&-\frac{29}{4} \\ x^{2}-7 x+\left(\frac{7}{2}\right)^{2} &=&-\frac{29}{4}+\left(\frac{7}{2}\right)^{2} \\ x^{2}-7 x+\frac{49}{4} &=&\frac{20}{4} \\ x^{2}-7 x+\frac{49}{4} &=&5 \\ \left(x-\frac{7}{2}\right)^{2} &=&5 \\ \sqrt{\left(x-\frac{7}{2}\right)^{2}} &=&\sqrt{5} \\ x-\frac{7}{2} &=&\pm \sqrt{5} \\ x&=&\frac{7}{2}\pm\sqrt{5} \\ x&=&\frac{7}{2}+\sqrt{5} \\ x&=&\frac{7}{2}-\sqrt{5} \\ x&=&\frac{7}{2}+\sqrt{5} \text { and } x=\frac{7}{2}-\sqrt{5} \end{array} \)

Activity Synthesis

Consider arranging students who solved the same equation in groups of two to three to discuss their strategies and then displaying the correct solutions for all to see.

Invite students to share their reflections on the solving process. Discuss questions such as:

  • "What method did you choose and why?"
  • "Did you find yourself choosing one method and then switching to another? If so, what prompted you to do that?"
  • "Did you run into any challenges when rewriting the equation (or completing the square)? What were some of the challenges?"

Acknowledge that all of these equations are cumbersome to solve by either rewriting in factored form or completing the square. The last equation cannot be written in factored form (with rational coefficients), so completing the square is the only way to go. Tell students they are about to learn a formula that gives the solutions to any quadratic equation.

9.6.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Use completing the square to solve \(2x^2+10x+8=0\).

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x= \frac{25}{4}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the value that completed the square. The equation then needs to be solved. The answer is \(x=-4, x=-1\).

\(x= 1, x =4\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Make sure to subtract the \(c\) from both sides before completing the square, not add the positive value. The answer is \(x=-4, x=-1\).

\(x=-4, x=-1\)

That's correct! Check yourself: After taking the square root of both sides, the equation becomes \(x=-\frac{5}{2} \pm \frac{3}{2}\).

\(x=-5 \pm \sqrt{17}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Divide all terms by the coefficient, 2, before completing the square, not just the first term. The answer is \(x=-4, x=-1\).

9.6.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Solve by Using Perfect Squares and Completing the Square 

Solve \(2x^2+5x+2=0\) by completing the square.

Step 1
Divide all terms by the leading coefficient.
\(\frac{2x^2+5x+2}{2}=\frac{0}{2}\)
\(x^2+\frac{5}{2}x+1=0\)

Step 2
Move the constant to the right side of the equation.
\(x^2+\frac{5}{2}x=-1\)

Step 3
Complete the square and add to each side: \((\frac{5}{2} \times \frac{1}{2})^2=\frac{25}{16}\).
\(x^2+\frac{5}{2}x+\frac{25}{16}=-1+\frac{25}{16}\)

Step 4
Simplify.  
(Hint: create a common denominator before adding.)
\(x^2+\frac{5}{2}x+\frac{25}{16}=-\frac{16}{16}+\frac{25}{16}\)
\((x+\frac{5}{4})^2=\frac{9}{16}\)

Step 5
Take the square root of each side.
\(\sqrt{(x+\frac{5}{4})^2}= \sqrt{\frac{9}{16}}\)
\(x+\frac{5}{4}= \pm \frac{3}{4}\)

Step 6
Write two equations and solve.
\(x+\frac{5}{4}=\frac{3}{4}\)          \(x+\frac{5}{4}=-\frac{3}{4}\)
\(x=-\frac{2}{4}=-\frac{1}{2}\)   \(x=-\frac{8}{4}=-2\)

Try It: Solve by Using Perfect Squares and Completing the Square

Solve \(4x^2+36x+37=0\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve using completing the square:

Step 1
Divide all terms by the leading coefficient.
\(\frac{4x^2+36x+37}{4}=\frac{0}{4}\)
\(x^2+9x+\frac{37}{4}=0\)

Step 2
Move the constant to the right side of the equation.
\(x^2+9x=-\frac{37}{4}\)

Step 3
Complete the square and add to each side: \((9 \times \frac{1}{2})^2=\frac{81}{4}\).
\(x^2+9x+\frac{81}{4}=-\frac{37}{4}+\frac{81}{4}\)

Step 4
Simplify.  
\((x+\frac{9}{2})^2=11\)

Step 5
Take the square root of each side.
\(\sqrt{(x+\frac{9}{2})^2}=\sqrt{11}\)
\((x+\frac{9}{2})= \pm \sqrt{11}\)

Step 6
Write two equations and solve.
\(x+\frac{9}{2}=\sqrt{11}\)       \(x+\frac{9}{2}=-\sqrt{11}\)
\(x=-\frac{9}{2}+\sqrt{11}\)       \(x=-\frac{9}{2}-\sqrt{11}\)

page.title: 9.6.3: The Quadratic Formula
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity introduces the quadratic formula. Students begin by applying the formula and using it to solve various equations, ranging from those that can be easily solved using other methods to the kinds that would be quite tedious to solve without the formula. They then verify that the formula gives the same solutions as those calculated by another method. Students notice that, for equations that cannot be easily rewritten using factored form or solved by completing the square, the formula offers quite an efficient way to find the solutions.

Launch

Display the equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) for all to see. Tell students that \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are numbers and \(a\) is not 0. Ask students if they could complete the square for this equation without first replacing \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) with numbers.

Explain that this can indeed be done! The outcome of completing the square is not going to be numerical solutions (because no numbers are used), but rather a general formula for finding the solutions of the quadratic equation. While students won't have to complete the square for this equation now, they will see the formula and try using it.

Display the quadratic formula for all to see. Tell students that when an equation is of the form \(ax2^+bx+c=0\), where \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are numbers and \(a\) is not 0, we can find its solutions by using the formula:

\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\).

Guide students through the steps of using the formula to find the solutions to \(x^2−8x+15=0\).

  • "First, what do we expect the solutions to be?" (3 and 5, because we can rewrite it as \((x−3)(x−5)=0)\).
  • "If \(x^2−8x+15\) is \(ax^2+bx+c\), what are the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\)?" \((a=1\),\(b=-8\), \(c=15)\).
  • Write out the formula as is.
  • Replace \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) with the corresponding numbers from the equation:

\(x=\frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^2- 4(1)(15)}}{2(1)}\).

  • Evaluate one part of the expression at a time, ending with x=3 and x=5.

Provide access to calculators for numerical computations.

If time is limited, ask students to complete at least two equations, including an equation in which the leading coefficient is not 1.

For students who are struggling with substitution, use different colors for \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) in the formula and for the numbers that are substituted into the formula.

Student Activity 

Here is a formula called the quadratic formula.

\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

The formula can be used to find the solutions to any quadratic equation in the form of \(ax^2+bx+c=0\), where \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are numbers and \(a\) is not 0.

This example shows how it is used to solve \(x^2−8x+15=0\), in which \(a=\)1, \(b=-8\), and \(c=15\).

Step 1
State the original equation.
\(x^2−8x+15=0\)

Step 2
Identify the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\).
\(a=1\), \(b=-8\), and \(c=15\)

Step 3
Substitute the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) into the formula.
\(x=\frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^2-(4)(1)(15)}}{2(1)}\)

Step 4
Evaluate each part of the expression.
\(x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{64-60}}{2}\)
\(x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{4}}{2}\)
\(x=\frac{8 \pm 2}{2}\)

Step 5
Write each equation separately and solve.
\(x=\frac{8+2}{2}\) and \(x=\frac{8-2}{2}\)

Step 6
Simplify.
\(x=\frac{10}{2}\) and \(x=\frac{6}{2}\) 

Step 7
Find the solutions.
\(x=5\) and \(x=3\)

Here are some quadratic equations and their solutions. Use the quadratic formula to show that the solutions are correct.

  1. \(x^2+4x−5=0\). The solutions are \(x=-5\) and \(x=1\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} x^{2}+4 x-5=0 \\ a=1, b=4, c=-5 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(4) \pm \sqrt{(4)^{2}-(4)(1)(-5)}}{2(1)} \\ x=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{16+20}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-4 \pm \sqrt{36}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-4 \pm 6}{2} \\ x=\frac{2}{2} \text { and } x=\frac{-10}{2} \\ x=1 \text { and } x=-5 \end{array}\)

  1. \(x^2+7x+12=0\). The solutions are \(x=-3\) and \(x=-4\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} x^{2}+7 x+12=0 \\ a=1, b=7, c=12 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(7) \pm \sqrt{(7)^{2}-(4)(1)(12)}}{2(1)} \\ x=\frac{-7 \pm \sqrt{49-48}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-7 \pm \sqrt{1}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-7 \pm 1}{2} \\ x=\frac{-6}{2} \text { and } x=\frac{-8}{2} \\ x=-3 \text { and } x=-4 \end{array}\)

  1. \(x^2+10x+18=0\). The solution is \(x=-5 \pm \frac{\sqrt{28}}{2}\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} x^{2}+10 x+18=0 \\ a=1, b=10, c=18 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(10) \pm \sqrt{(10)^{2}-(4)(1)(18)}}{2(1)} \\ x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100-72}}{2} \\ x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{28}}{2} \\ x=-5 \pm \frac{\sqrt{28}}{2} \end{array}\)

  1. \(x^2−8x+11=0\). The solution is \(x=4 \pm \frac{\sqrt{20}}{2}\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} x^{2}-8 x+11=0 \\ a=1, b=-8, c=11 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(-8) \pm \sqrt{(-8)^{2}-(4)(1)(11)}}{2(1)} \\ x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{64-44}}{2} \\ x=\frac{8 \pm \sqrt{20}}{2} \\ x=4 \pm \frac{\sqrt{20}}{2} \end{array} \)

  1. \(9x^2−6x+1=0\). The solution is \(x=\frac{1}{3}\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} 9 x^{2}-6 x+1=0 \\ a=9, b=-6, c=1 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(-6) \pm \sqrt{(-6)^{2}-(4)(9)(1)}}{2(9)} \\ x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{36-36}}{18} \\ x=\frac{6}{18} \\ x=\frac{1}{3} \end{array} \)

  1. \(6x^2+9x−15=0\). The solutions are \(x=-\frac{5}{2}\) and \(x=1\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer:

\(\begin{array}{l} 6 x^{2}+9 x-15=0 \\ a=6, b=9, c=-15 \\ x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^{2}-4 a c}}{2 a} \\ x=\frac{-(9) \pm \sqrt{(9)^{2}-(4)(6)(-15)}}{2(6)} \\ x=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{81-(-360)}}{12} \\ x=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{441}}{12} \\ x=\frac{-9 \pm 21}{12} \\ x=\frac{-9+21}{12} \\ x=\frac{-9-21}{12} \\ x=\frac{12}{12}=1 \\ x=\frac{-30}{12}=\frac{-5}{2} \end{array}\)

Video: Solving Quadratics With the Quadratic Formula

Watch the following video to learn more about solving quadratics with the quadratic formula.



Activity Synthesis

Much of the student discussion will have happened in small groups. Focus the whole-class conversation on whether the quadratic formula works for solving all equations and when it might be a preferred method. Ask students:

  • "Look at the list of equations and the work you did to solve them. Do certain equations lend themselves to certain methods of solving? Why?" (We can see the factors of some expressions right away, so rewriting it in factored form would be the quickest method to solve the equations. Other expressions cannot be easily rewritten in factored form but can be easily transformed into perfect squares. For example, when the coefficient of x2 is 1, the coefficient of the linear term is an even number, and the constant term is also a whole number, completing the square is straightforward. When the squared term has a coefficient other than 1, the other two methods are less practical, so the quadratic formula may be the quickest approach.)
  • "Why do you think the quadratic formula is useful only when the \(a\) in ax2+bx+c=0 is not 0?" (If \(a\) is 0, the expression is no longer quadratic because the squared term disappears, leaving only bx+c, which is linear.)

Select students who used the quadratic formula to solve the last few equations to explain their solutions and display their work for all to see. Discuss any challenges or disagreements in using the formula.

Tell students that they will use the formula to solve other equations and find out more about its merits and how it compares to other methods of solving.

Watch for algebraic errors with negatives when a value is substituted in for \(b\) when it is made negative and also squared in the formula.

9.6.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Solve \(2x^2-6x+3=0\) using the quadratic formula.

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

\(x=\frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Remember the formula begins with \(-b\). The correct answer is \(x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4}\).

\(x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4}\)

That's correct! Check yourself: Substitute \(a = 2\), \(b = -6\), and \(c = 3\) into the quadratic formula then simplify.

\(x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{60}}{4}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Be sure to subtract \(4ac\) from \(b^2\), not add. The correct answer is \(x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4}\).

\(x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{-12}}{4}\)

Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Remember, when you square a negative number, like in \((-6)^2\), it equals a positive. The correct answer is \(x=\frac{6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4}\). 

9.6.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Solving With the Quadratic Formula


Quadratic Formula 

The solutions to a quadratic equation of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\), where \(a \neq 0\), are given by the formula:

\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)



To use the quadratic formula, we substitute the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) from the standard form into the expression on the right side of the formula. Then we simplify the expression. The result is the pair of solutions to the quadratic equation.

Notice the formula is an equation. Make sure you use both sides of the equation.

How to Solve a Quadratic Equation Using the Quadratic Formula

Solve by using the quadratic formula: \(2x^2+9x-5=0\).

Step 1
Write the quadratic equation in standard form.  
This equation is in standard form.
\({\style{color:red}a}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}b}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}c}{\style{color:red}=}{\style{color:red}0}\)
\(2x^2+9x-5=0\)

Step 2
Identify the \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) values.
\( a=2\), \(b=9\), \(c=-5\)

Step 3
Write the quadratic formula.  
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 4
Then substitute in the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\).
\({\style{color:blue}a}{\style{color:blue}=}{\style{color:blue}2}\), \({\style{color:red}b}{\style{color:red}=}{\style{color:red}9}\), \({\style{color:green}c}{\style{color:green}=}{\style{color:green}-}{\style{color:green}5}\)
\(x=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{9^2- 4 \cdot 2 \cdot (-5)}}{2 \cdot 2}\)

Step 5
Simplify the fraction and solve for \(x\).
\(x=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{81-(-40)}}{4}\)
\(x=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{121}}{4}\)
\(x=\frac{-9 +11}{4}\)   \(x=\frac{-9-11}{4}\)
\(x=\frac{2}{4}\)           \(x=\frac{-20}{4}\)
\(x=\frac{1}{2}\)           \(x=-5\)

Step 6
Check the solutions.
Put each answer in the original equation to check.
Substitute \(x=\frac{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}2}\).

\(\begin{array}{l} 2\left(\frac{{\style{color:red}1}}{{\style{color:red}2}}\right)^{2}+9 \cdot \frac{{\style{color:red}1}}{{\style{color:red}2}}-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ 2\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)+9 \cdot \frac{1}{2}-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ \frac{2}{4}+\frac{9}{2}-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ \frac{1}{2}+\frac{9}{2}-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ \frac{10}{2}-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ 5-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ 0=0 \text{ ✔} \end{array}\)

Substitute \(x={\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}\).

\(\begin{array}{l} 2({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5})^{2}+9({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5})-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ 2(25)-45-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ 50-45-5 \stackrel{?}{=} 0 \\ 0=0 \text{ ✔} \end{array}\)

Try It: Solving With the Quadratic Formula

Solve \(2x^2+10x+11=0\) using the quadratic formula.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Here is how to solve this quadratic equation using the quadratic formula:

Solve by using the quadratic formula: \(2x^2+10x+11=0\).

Step 1
This equation is in standard form.
\({\style{color:red}a}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}b}{\style{color:red}x}{\style{color:red}+}{\style{color:red}c}{\style{color:red}=}{\style{color:red}0}\)
\(2x^2+10x+11=0\)

Step 2
Identify the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\).
\(a=2\), \(b=10\), \(c=11\)

Step 3
Write the quadratic formula.
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 4
Then substitute in the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\).
Substitute in:
\({\style{color:blue}a}{\style{color:blue}=}{\style{color:blue}2}\), \({\style{color:red}b}{\style{color:red}=}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}0}\), \({\style{color:green}c}{\style{color:green}=}{\style{color:green}1}{\style{color:green}1}\)

\(x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{10^2- 4 \cdot 2 \cdot (11)}}{2 \cdot 2}\)

Step 5
Simplify.
\(x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100-88}}{4}\)
\(x=\frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{12}}{4}\)

Simplify the radical expression.
\(x=\frac{-10 \pm 2 \sqrt{3}}{4}\)

Factor out the common factor in the numerator.
\(x=\frac{2(-5 \pm \sqrt{3})}{4}\)

Remove the common factors.
\(x=\frac{-5 \pm \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Rewrite to show two solutions.
\(x=\frac{-5 + \sqrt{3}}{2}\), \(x=\frac{-5 - \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Step 6
Check the solutions.
Put each answer in the original equation to check.
Substitute \(x=\frac{{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red} +} \sqrt{{\style{color:red}3}}}{{\style{color:red}2}}\).

\(\begin{array}{l} 2\left[\left(\frac{{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}}{{\style{color:red}2}}{\style{color:red}+}\frac{\sqrt{{\style{color:red}3}}}{{\style{color:red}2}}\right)\left(\frac{{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}}{{\style{color:red}2}}{\style{color:red}+}\frac{\sqrt{{\style{color:red}3}}}{{\style{color:red}2}}\right)\right]+10\left(\frac{-5+\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 2\left[\frac{25}{4}-\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{4}-\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\right]+5(-5+\sqrt{3})+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ \left.2\left[\frac{25}{4}-\frac{10 \sqrt{3}}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\right]+(-25)+5 \sqrt{3}\right)+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ \frac{25}{2}-\frac{10 \sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{3}{2}-14+5 \sqrt{3}\stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ \frac{28}{2}-5 \sqrt{3}-14-5 \sqrt{3} \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 14-5 \sqrt{3}-14+5 \sqrt{3}\stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 0=0 \text{ ✔} \end{array}\)

Substitute \(x=\frac{{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red} -} \sqrt{{\style{color:red}3}}}{{\style{color:red}2}}\).

\(\begin{array}{l} 2\left(\frac{{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}-}\sqrt{{\style{color:red}3}}}{{\style{color:red}2}}\right)^{2}+10 \cdot \frac{{\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}5}{\style{color:red}-}\sqrt{{\style{color:red}3}}}{{\style{color:red}2}}+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 2\left[\left(\frac{-5}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\left(\frac{-5}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)\right]+10\left(\frac{-5-\sqrt{3}}{2}\right)+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 2\left[\frac{25}{4}+\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{4}+\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\right]+5(-5-\sqrt{3})+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ \left.2\left[\frac{25}{4}+\frac{10 \sqrt{3}}{4}+\frac{3}{4}\right]+(-25)-5 \sqrt{3}\right)+11 \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ \frac{25}{2}+\frac{10 \sqrt{3}}{2}+\frac{3}{2}-14-5 \sqrt{3} \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ \frac{28}{2}+5 \sqrt{3}-14-5 \sqrt{3} \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 14+5 \sqrt{3}-14-5 \sqrt{3} \stackrel{?}{=} 0\\ 0=0 \text{ ✔} \end{array}\)

page.title: 9.6.4: Solving Equations Using the Quadratic Formula
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Activity

Here is the quadratic formula:

\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\)

Use the formula to solve the equation \(x^2+9x+8=0\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Answer: The solutions are -8 and -1.

Apply the quadratic formula for \(a=1\), \(b=9\), \(c=8\):

\(x=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{(9)^2- 4(1)(8)}}{2(1)}=\frac{-9 \pm \sqrt{49}}{2}\), which means

\(x=\frac{-9-7}{2}=-8\) and \(x=\frac{-9+7}{2}=-1\).

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 9.6.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

For each equation in questions 1–5, identify the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) that you would substitute into the quadratic formula to solve the equation.

  1. \(3x^2+8x+4=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 3

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 8

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: 4

  1. \(2x^2−5x+2=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 2

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: -5

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: 2

  1. \(-9x^2+13x−1=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: -9

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 13

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: -1

  1. \(x^2+x−11=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 1

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 1

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: -11

  1. \(-x^2+16x+64=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: -1

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 16

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: 64

  1. For each equation, use the quadratic formula to solve the equation, then choose the correct two solutions for \(x\). 
  1. \(x^2+9x+20=0\)
  • 4
  • -4
  • -5
  • 5
  • 1
  • 9
  • 20

Answer: -4, -5

  1. \(x^2−10x+21=0\)
  • 3
  • -7
  • 21
  • -10
  • 1
  • -4
  • 7

Answer: 3, 7

  1. \(3x^2−5x+1=0\)
  • \(\frac{13}{6}+\frac{\sqrt{5}}{6}\)
  • -1
  • \(\frac{5}{6}-\frac{\sqrt{13}}{6}\)
  • \(\frac{13}{6}-\frac{\sqrt{5}}{6}\)
  • \(-\frac{18}{6}-3\)
  • \(\frac{5}{6}+\frac{\sqrt{13}}{6}\)
  • \(\frac{18}{6}-3\)

Answer:\(\frac{5}{6}+\frac{\sqrt{13}}{6}\), \(\frac{5}{6}-\frac{\sqrt{13}}{6}\)

For each equation for questions 7–12, identify the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) that you would substitute into the quadratic formula to solve the equation.

  1. \(x^2+9x+18=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 1

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 9

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: 18

  1. \(4x^2−3x+11=0\)
  1. a. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 4

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: -3

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: 11

  1. \(81−x+5x^2=0\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 5

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: -1

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: 81

  1. \(45x^2+3x=\frac{1}{3}\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 45

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 3

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?
  • \(-\frac{1}{3}\)
  • \(\frac{1}{3}\)
  • 1
  • 0

Answer:\(-\frac{1}{3}\)

  1. \(121=x^2\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 1

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 0

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: -121

  1. \(7x+14x^2=42\)
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Answer: 14

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Answer: 7

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Answer: -42

page.title: 9.6.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Display the equation \(25x^2−50x+16=0\) for all to see. Ask students how they prefer to solve it (by rewriting the expression in factored form, completing the square, or using the quadratic formula) and why. Then, ask them to solve the equation using their preferred method.

Possible explanations for the different methods:

  • Rewriting in factored form: The equation can be rewritten as \((5x−8)(5x−2)=0\) and solved using the zero product property.
  • Completing the square: \(25x^2−50x+25\) is a perfect square, so we can just add 9 to either side of the original equation and find the square root of 9.
  • The quadratic formula, because it always works.

The solutions (by any method) are \(\frac25\) and \(\frac85\).
